6) Making The Leap

Regardless of your seniority level, it‚Äôs a good time to explore web3 companies. @opensea, @hellodapper, @AlchemyPlatform, @usebraintrust, @DuneAnalytics, and @coinbase are all great companies that are hiring.

5) Writing Is Key

Writing allows me to construct my thinking and see if I understand what I am talking about. Writing also helps you with relationship building. It just takes a few influential people to read your writing to get noticed and invited to share your perspective.

4) Ease Of Information Gathering

If you are interested in investing in a project or token, you have a lot of public information you can gather to make that investment. If you are interested in working at a web3 company, you can make a more data-driven decision on your career.

3) Knowledge Flywheels

Raising your hand and saying you're interested in a topic accelerates your learnings. People come to you with questions. Even if you do not know them, you'll go figure it out, share knowledge, which will lead to more folks looking for your guidance.

2) Web3 Paradoxes

If you look deep enough you can see the potential of web3, or you might see the opposite. Just like any new technology (e.g. social media), both can be true. It‚Äôs up to the early builders and users to dictate which direction this goes.

1) Wisdom + Enthusiasm = Opportunity

Matching the wisdom from web2 with the enthusiasm of web3 will lead you to a good place. You can get excited, be open-minded, but also be rigorous in your thinking.

It's been a few months since I started writing about web3. 

Since then I've connected with web3 founders, investors, and web2 execs exploring this space.

RT @chriscantino: 1/ The future of NFTs. üßµ

RT @chriscantino: ‚ÄúSoulbound‚Äù NFTs

NFTs are lauded for their transferability, but there are many use cases for non-transferable tokens: dr‚Ä¶

I know I‚Äôll be one of the first set of consumers to test out how this will work. Stay tuned.¬†

https://t.co/NxNsHtOcji

Consumers will be able to create a deeper relationship with merchants through NFTs. Eg,¬†if you buy shoes from Nike, you‚Äôll get an NFT of that shoe, access to a community of fellow shoe owners, which could lead to more brand loyalty

Merchants have only been able to accept BTC or ETH in the past. This is too volatile for business owners to use or save. USDC is the US dollar but in cryptocurrency. Once you purchase USDC, using the token is faster and easier to use than Venmo, Apple Pay, etc

@solana pay was announced this week. This will allow merchants to be able to accept USDC, through users' Solana wallets. Merchants have been able to accept cryptocurrency in the past, but there is reason to believe that this product may lead to more adoption for the following..
@lchoii_ Can we go together?

your employment history, and verification of the college you went to. All of this data will live on your wallet for you to showcase, use for your next job, or maybe even get discounts at your local coffee shop.¬†Excited to see how this area evolves. 2/2

Showing my NFTs feels similar to sharing photos from a recent trip; there‚Äôs a story behind it and people I experienced it with, so you feel a sense of pride while sharing. In the future, your wallet will not only hold your NFTs and tokens, but also your driver's license 1/2

It's becoming clear to me that new users do not care about decentralization for the sake of decentralization. Users want products that are:
1.) Easy to use
2.) Cheap to use
3.) Provide value

Interesting to hear Vitalik share a similar sentiment as well.

"A lot of people care about decentralization, but they are not going to accept decentralization if it costs $8 a transaction" - @VitalikButerin on the @BanklessHQ pod.

3. Listen deeper to myself, others, and the world. 

Society is noisy and rarely are we silent. Silent with ourselves in reflection, silent when speaking with others, and silent when experiencing nature. Silence is required for listening, and listening is required for learning.

2. Engineering serendipity.

Most of my life's pivotal moments have been through a seemingly random exchange of ideas in chance encounters with diverse people. That could be writing, building community, introducing people to one another, and more.

1. To win and help others win; emotionally, spiritually, and financially. 

How we win is multidimensional and subjective. I know what that looks like for me, and will be supporting whatever that looks like for you. Shoutout @balajis for this idea!
